question: Detective Dormer!

Detective Eckhart! I know! Welcome to Nightmute! I just want to say how incredible it is to have you working with us, Detective Dormer. I've followed all your cases. Theodore Dineli, Frank and Casey Prud'homme, the Port Angeles shootings... Sure thing, Spence.
I told you seven years ago this was a stepping stone to retirement.
What's the D.A. got them on?
answer: Four unwarranted shootings, witness intimidation, and cocaine theft.

question: Beaten to death.
Superficial.
None.
Wait.
No fibers, skin flakes, hairs...
answer: Like I said, no. We know about those things up here.

question: Even the best make mistakes.
Lower forty-eight?
answer: You're not from here. I can tell by your walk.

question: Oh? And how's that?
Unsure.
answer: Detectives Will Dormer and Hap Eckhart. There should be a reservation for us.

question: Your friend's all business.
Me.
See you have the same decor as my room.
answer: What do you want to talk about?

question: You know what about.
answer: We'll talk when we get back to Seattle.

question: When's that, a week? Two weeks?... We have to figure out a plan of action now.
answer: You know my plan of action.

question: To do nothing.
Dammit, Will. Warfield had me locked up in his office again for five hours yesterday. Five hours. Asking all kinds of questions...
But he's zeroing in on me. On us. Everyone's talking about it.
Well, I gotta tell you. With a wife, three kids, and a pension plan in the balance, it's rattling hard.
answer: We say nothing. It goes away. Simple as that.

question: Look. We've tampered with evidence. We've pushed witnesses. We've planted shit. And they're sniffing around like dogs. Especially on the Dobbs case...
answer: Weston Dobbs killed an eight year-old boy and left him hanging in the basement like a piece of meat. You remember that?

question: You know I remember that.
answer: One word to I.A. and he walks.

question: Maybe not. We could talk to Buck...
Cut some kind of a deal. I heard that's what Flynn's doing...
answer: Mike Flynn's a dirty cop, Hap! We are nothing like Mike Flynn. We did what we needed to do to make sure that son-of- bitch Dobbs paid for what he did. And every bastard like him. We say one word about it and every case we ever brought in is going to blow wide open and they'll all walk. Every last one. And I am not going to let that happen. No deals. No compromises. No discussions.

question: Goddammit, Will. You grab on to something and you don't let it go. I don't know if it's because you think it's the right thing to do or because your pride won't let you do anything else. I can't tell any more. But I can tell you one thing. I'm getting too old for this cowboy cop stuff. Breaking the rules. Cleaning up messes. We're a dying breed, Will. You're a dying breed. I.A., the D.A., all those reporters - they don't care what you did at Leland Street seven years ago. They don't care that you've made this your life. They don't care about getting the bad guy...
answer: I care. You got to be kidding me.

question: I care. You got to be kidding me.
answer: Fred wants us to meet him at the Connell's. Brought you a bear claw. Just in case you were hungry.

question: Think I'll pass.
answer: Oh. You know. Small-time stuff. Nothing like what you must get. Mostly drinking-related problems. Domestic abuse. Barroom fights. Stuff like that.

question: Don't give misdemeanors a bad rap.
answer: But they're so boring. All small stuff.

question: It's all about the small stuff. Small lies. Small mistakes. Small oversights. People give themselves away in a traffic violation just as much as they do in a murder case. It's human nature.
Typical seventeen year-old. She went to a party Friday night?
answer: Down at a local dive the kids like to hang out in.

question: No diary.
answer: She left the party early. Friends said she had a fight with her boyfriend and stormed out.

question: What time was that?
Who was the last one to see her alive?
answer: Randy Stetz. Her boyfriend. We've questioned him, searched his place. Didn't find anything.

question: Did you love her?
Kay Connell. Did you love her?
"She was nice." Wow. That makes me all soft inside. Ever occur to you she didn't love you back?
You heard me that time.
answer: She loved me. She wanted to see me every night.

question: But she was seeing someone else on the side.
answer: I don't know what you're fucking talking about.

question: Friday night, at the party - what'd you fight about?
What kind of stuff?
answer: Just stuff. I don't fucking remember.

question: The other guy?
answer: I told you I don't remember.

question: After that she left the party to go to him.
Ran like hell to go to him...
answer: Fuck you, man! - I'm sick of all your fucking cop questions...

question: Now you listen to me, you little shit. This fuck-the-world-Metallica-t-shirt crap may work with your mamma, but it doesn't work with me. You got mad at your girlfriend because she was seeing someone else. You want to be the last person who saw her alive or are you going to tell me who that is?
You don't know.
He's a little surly, isn't he?
answer: Just a little. I want you to check this out, Ellie.

question: We already did.
But there wasn't any...
answer: The small things - remember? The second you're about to dismiss something - look at it again.

question: You want me to write that down?
The bartender at Darrow's. He was there Friday night.
answer: Good. He's up next. Halibut Calabrese. Halibut Olympia. Halibut Cajun Style. Halibut fish and chips...

question: Good. He's up next. Halibut Calabrese. Halibut Olympia. Halibut Cajun Style. Halibut fish and chips...
Looks like the natives are restless.
answer: Will? I wish I could stick it out like you. I just, with Trish and the kids...

question: Don't do this, Hap...
answer: I'm thinking I could get off with probation. Keep half my pension. That's all I want.

question: Goddammit, Hap. Think about what you're doing...
answer: You don't have to be involved, Will.

question: Go! Go! Go! Police!
Where is he?
And then you lost him.
answer: And then I lost him. In the fog.

question: About how long 'til you heard the suspect's second shot?
answer: Twenty, thirty seconds. I followed the sound down to the water. That's where...

question: I think you need a glass of this.
answer: Why didn't I know about that goddamn tunnel, Charlie?

question: There's a bunch of those tunnels out there, Will. From bunkers over sixty years old. I don't even know half of them myself, and I grew up here.
answer: I had him, Charlie. Right in front of me. Not two feet. I could smell the son- of-a-bitch. Playing with me. And I missed the shot. He was right there and I missed the shot! Then my goddamned gun jammed...

question: Will, you can't blame yourself.
It's only gonna make you crazy.
Right, Ellie.
answer: But what about the Connell case? I'm on the Connell case.

question: Detective Dormer!
Oh, a real tear-jerker. Brody, the good guy, just got shot.
I wish I'd had the chance to get to know him better. Take him fishing or something.
We just gotta catch the bastard, right?
answer: That's why I'm here. I need to know exactly what you saw yesterday, Farrell.

question: What I saw?

Pretty much nothing. That fog was so thick. The bullet seemed to come out of nowhere. I don't even remember seeing any shapes. Then I saw you. But only when you came up close. Then you disappeared again. I guess I heard more than I saw.
answer: No. No. Don't be sorry. It's not your fault.

question: Lonnie and I went to high school together.
Oh, you know. Don't feel that much. Bullet went right through.
answer: Right. Got lost in the rocks.

question: ...and it was at this point that Detective Dormer headed towards the noise...
You're supposed to be Farrell. Shot in the thigh and writhing in pain.
Accuracy. That's what. Now get down.
The woods. One group heading south, the other heading north.
answer: Make sure they're set to channel 6...

question: Anything? Alright. Go back and set up some follow- ups for this afternoon.
answer: You don't think they should start further back?

question: He had to have exited here. Over those boulders. I saw him move, he's nimble. Would have taken the hardest way out.
Here. It's on the house.
I got it. Don't know why I bother. It's been broken for two years.
No. He didn't say what his name was. Only that you were expecting him.
That's not what he thinks.
Short. Dark hair. Not that memorable.
answer: I need to borrow something. I could say the same thing about you.

question: I need to borrow something. I could say the same thing about you.
answer: Oh. We always have play-offs in the middle of the night. It's the best time.

question: Who's playing?
answer: The Puffins and the Hawks. We're in extra innings. The Hawks have a really good line-up this year. That's my sister.

question: She your only sibling?
No. Well. I had a brother. He died when I was eleven.
It's okay. Happened a long time ago. He was killed in a fire. In New Mexico.
answer: That must have been awful for you.

question: Not really. I remember I was more embarrassed that he had died. Embarrassed that it made me different. So I didn't tell the other kids at school what had happened. They'd ask me where he was, where he'd gone. And I'd make up stories. He was visiting an aunt up north, he'd broken his leg, he was in a Swiss boarding school. Stuff like that. Nice kid, huh? Just kept making up more and more lies...
I'm going back to the Lodge, Ellie. Still need to go through some of Kay Connell's school records.
Officer!... I'll pick it up. You head back to the station. Duggar - I'm at the coroner's now. I'll be back in about twenty minutes...
answer: Detective. Thought you were sending one of your lackeys.

question: I thought it was better if I came. Under the circumstances.
answer: It's different when you know them, isn't it? Just sign over there and she's all yours. Your partner didn't suffer much...

question: Thanks, Doc.
answer: You're looking a little green, Detective.

question: So where's the other bullets? What's with all the moose antlers around here?
When's Rich coming?
First I need a copy of the key.
answer: This isn't Seattle, Detective. We don't have copies. This is the only one.

question: Dormer.
answer: I bet you haven't been getting much sleep.

question: What?
answer: You lower-48s. You think the white nights are kind of neat. Then you can't sleep for days. I've seen it happen about a million times. But you can't sleep for a different reason.

question: Who is this? I said, who is this?
answer: I saw what really happened, Will... I saw you kill your partner. With your back-up weapon. Out there on the beach. I saw you shoot him dead...

question: Now you listen to me...
answer: Don't worry. I won't tell anyone. Oh, and I saw you take my gun. My uncle's old 357. I dropped it in the rocks. But you can go ahead and keep that.

question: Detective Dormer! You look like you're in a hurry. I just wanted to ask you about these pictures.
But here's the thing. I retraced your exact steps according to your statement. You couldn't have seen Detective Eckhart from there. I mean, not in that fog.
How much closer would you say you were?
Five feet? Seven feet?
answer: Listen, Ellie. I don't have time for this shit. Five feet, seven feet, twenty feet. Put down whatever you want in your report, alright?

question: I never met anyone from Seattle before.
What are you doing in this shit-hole town?
answer: You were good friends with Kay Connell, weren't you?

question: I was her best friend.
Since grade school.
We were like sisters. Knew everything about each other.
answer: Must be tough for you. What happened.

question: Everybody says I'm holding up great, considering. Don't even care if I go to school. They're all worried I haven't cried yet.
Do we have to talk about Kay? I don't want to talk about her right now. Let's just drive. Go somewhere.
answer: You want me to take you somewhere?

question: Long as it's fun.
answer: How about this. You like this?

question: Hey...
Move over! You crazy son-of-a-bitch! You could have killed us!
answer: You and Kay were like sisters?

question: That's what I said.
answer: Told each other everything. That why your picture's torn up in the top drawer of her bureau?

question: No...
answer: Who was Kay seeing besides Randy Stetz?

question: I don't know.
She wouldn't tell me!
answer: But you were such good friends...

question: It was like some big fucking secret!
She kept saying she was gonna get out of here. Leave us all behind. That he was going to take her!
My arm!
She used some stupid code name.
Brody...I don't know... ...Something Brody!
Lucy. Desi. Goddammit!
What?
answer: I beeped you over two hours ago.

question: Good.
answer: And something else that might interest you.

question: No.
answer: One of the paperbacks we found in Kay Connell's knapsack.

question: That's right.
answer: Mrs. Connell found this copy in the house. It's signed. Personally.

question: So?
answer: This is a local writer. Kay had all his books. I think we should check it out.

question: I'm fine. Walter Byrd.
answer: When I was seven my mother and grandmother took me to Vancouver. We were walking along the street one day when these two men ran past and snatched my grandmother's purse right from under her arm. Right from under her arm. That night a police officer came to our hotel room to ask us questions. Stood the whole time. You know this glacier moves a quarter of an inch every day?

question: You think this is a nice meeting we're having here? Friendly? Two people getting acquainted? You sick, coward, fuck. I get up every morning of my life just to bring someone like you down. Beating a seventeen year- old girl to death. Washing her afterwards, cleaning her. Make you feel like a real man? Huh?
answer: I stood right behind you...I saw you look right into his eyes and shoot him...

question: That was an accident! You hear me? I didn't know it was him! I didn't know it was him!
What's your game, Byrd?
The phone call. The knapsack.
answer: I figured we're partners on this one. I mean, after what I saw...

question: Let's get one thing straight, Byrd. We are partners on nothing.
answer: I research my novels. I know the procedures. You'd have cuffed me back at the ferry. You'd have called for back- up, read me my rights, and gotten a search warrant for my apartment. You're a well-respected detective. There's no reason for you to be talking to me right now...

question: You're going to get a phone call.
I said you're going to get a phone call.
Kay Connell had a signed copy of one of your books.
You're going to be brought in for questioning.
Yes down at the station.
answer: Okay. Okay. Brought in for questioning. Good. I can write this.

question: What do you mean, "wild card?"
What do you mean "wild card?"
I have a cold.
Back to the Lodge.
answer: I needed to get your signature on something.

question: I trust you. Duggar called him?
answer: About an hour ago. Said he was more than happy to cooperate.

question: Not really.
answer: Isn't that the difference between a good cop and a bad cop? A good cop can't sleep 'cause a piece of the puzzle's missing. A bad cop can't sleep 'cause his conscience won't let him. You said that once, remember?

question: No. But it sounds like something I would've said.
answer: Oh! I forgot to tell you. The Puffins won.

question: Fuck!
What is it?
answer: There's a guy down the hall. Complaining about the noise. Says he can't sleep. Are you alright?

question: I'm fine.
No.
The light. It keeps coming in...

There was this guy named Weston Dobbs. Twenty-four. Worked as a part-time stock boy in a copy store. Every morning he'd sit at the only window in his apartment and watch an eight year-old boy get picked up by his carpool across the street. And every afternoon he'd watch the boy get dropped off again. He did this for about six months. Until one day he got up the nerve to cross the street and grab the boy before his carpool came. Kept him in his apartment for three days. Tortured him. Raped him. Made him do things...

Me and Hap. A year and a half ago. I knew the second I met Dobbs that he was guilty. Smug, cold. Dead eyes. We had circumstantial evidence, but nothing to tie him to it. Nothing concrete. Went over every inch of that apartment.
We took some blood samples from the boy's body and planted them in his apartment. Arrested him the next day.
There've been other cases. Where we've changed results. Pushed witnesses. Manipulated evidence. But Dobbs. I wanted Dobbs more than anything.
We're under investigation now. Back in Seattle. Hap wanted to talk. As soon as we got back. Thought he could work out some kind of deal.
answer: Well, that's not going to happen now.

question: Do you think it was wrong? What we did?
answer: There are two kinds of people in Alaska. Those who were born here and those who've come here to escape something in their lives. I wasn't born here, Will. I'm in no position to judge anyone. I'm not about that any more.

question: A year ago. At one of my signings.
That's right.
She flattered me about my writing. Asked if she could visit me. To talk about my books.
Yes. Not that much at first. But then she became more comfortable. Started visiting me every week...
answer: What was the nature of your relationship?

question: What do you mean, Detective Dormer?
answer: She was an attractive girl. Did you have sex with her?

question: She was only seventeen.
answer: But she was an attractive girl.

question: I suppose.
answer: Did you have sex with her?

question: No.
I was a mentor to her.
Yes.
Yes.
answer: Doesn't sound like a mentor to me.

question: I gave her things she didn't have. Couldn't have.
answer: We understand, Mr. Byrd. You want to sit down, Detective?

question: She wasn't happy. I was someone to talk to.
That boyfriend. Randy.
He. Well, he...
answer: Mr. Byrd. Anything you can tell us could help out with this case.

question: Well. He hit her.
You can't fucking do this! Hey! I'm working on that! What the fuck is that!
That's not mine, man! That's not mine!
No way, man!
I swear to God. I didn't kill her. I swear to God...
It's a legitimate point, isn't it, Detective Dormer?
Worth pursuing?
answer: The case is closed, Ellie. I got the next round.

question: Hi, Will...
answer: What the hell are you doing calling me at the station?

question: I figured we should touch base. Compare notes. I think it went well. What did you think?
Told you I could write an ending.
I thought maybe we could talk some more.
answer: There's nothing more to talk about.

question: But we work so well together...
answer: We do nothing well together. Nothing! You understand me?

question: You run on two settings, Will. I've noticed that...
answer: What the hell do you know?

question: Kay told me. She comes to me, you know. Tells me things. About you. About me.
answer: I told you that was an accident!

question: Then so was mine...
answer: Don't you pull that shit with me.

question: I didn't want to kill her, Will.
It was when I went to kiss her. She started laughing. I got angry. After all I'd given her. All I'd shared with her. I just wanted to make her stop. That's all.
Yes. Like that.
If you want it to be...
answer: It took ten minutes to beat Kay Connell to death. Ten minutes.

question: Didn't want to miss anything.
answer: Detective Dormer's not leaving for a few hours.

question: Good.
answer: Maybe you could drive him to Spencer's.

question: Sure.
Very funny, Farrell... Hi, Rachel.
answer: I would have seen if he came back.

question: Detective Dormer?
Here to visit me?
Where's your back-up?
You're not following procedure.
answer: Procedure went out the window a long time ago.

question: We're on the same side, Will. You know that. After what we've been through together. We're partners. Bound by a secret.
Walter?
Drop the gun, Walter.
answer: That jammed the last time, remember?
